nodes.text: Absolute income mobility in the United States (fraction of children earning more than their parents) has changed across birth cohorts from 1940 to 1984 and can be quantified using marginal income distributions and the copula of parent and child income ranks

We estimate absolute mobility by decomposing the joint distribution of parent and child incomes into (i) the marginal distribution of child incomes, (ii) the marginal distribution of parent incomes, and (iii) the copula of parent and child income ranks, with absolute mobility equal to the integral over rank pairs where child quantile is at least parent quantile

We combine cross-sectional Census and CPS marginal income distributions (children and parents at age 30, measured in real 2014 dollars) with a nonparametric copula estimated from de-identified tax records for cohorts born 1980-1982; for pre-1980 cohorts we assume copula stability and also compute bounds over all plausible copulas using linear programming

We define plausible copulas by imposing first-order stochastic dominance (FOSD) of child income distributions as parental rank increases and row/column integration constraints; bounds on absolute mobility are obtained by linear programming over a 100x100 percentile matrix

Baseline measurement choices: family pretax income at age 30, CPI-U-RS inflation adjustment, exclusion of immigrants for comparability, and treatment of zero-income parents as yielding 100% mobility for their children

Children's marginal income distributions are obtained from CPS March samples (1970-2014) for 1940-1984 birth cohorts, excluding immigrants (where observed) and computing family income as sum of spouses' pretax income

Parents' marginal income distributions are constructed from pooled decennial Census IPUMS cross sections (1940-2000), selecting parents with children and using age windows around 30 to approximate parents' incomes when children were born

Empirical result: Under the copula stability benchmark, average absolute mobility fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to about 50% for the 1984 birth cohort; declines are largest in middle and upper parent percentiles

Bounding result: Searching over all copulas satisfying FOSD yields tight bounds for early cohorts (e.g., 1940 cohort mobility bounded 84% to 98%) but wide bounds for recent cohorts, implying robust decline in mobility despite missing historical panel data

Copula stability evidence: Tax record analyses show relative rank copula is approximately stable from 1971 to 1984, motivating baseline application of 1980-1982 copula to earlier cohorts while still reporting bounds

Sensitivity analyses show findings are robust to alternative inflation deflators, measuring income after taxes and transfers, measuring incomes at age 40, adjusting for family size, using individual versus family income, and plausible upward adjustments to reported incomes

Heterogeneity: Absolute mobility declined in all 50 states between 1940 and 1980 with largest declines in industrial Midwest; by gender, sons' individual chance of out-earning fathers fell sharply while daughters' trends differ due to rising female labor force participation

Counterfactual simulations: Increasing GDP growth for 1980 cohort to mid-century per-family growth rates (2.5% annually) with the 2010 distribution of income raises mean absolute mobility from 50% to 62%; reallocating 2010 GDP according to 1940 income shares raises mean mobility to 80%

Interpretation: Most of the decline in absolute mobility is driven by a more unequal distribution of economic growth across income groups rather than by the slowdown in aggregate GDP growth alone, because unequal growth concentrates gains among high earners and leaves many children unable to surpass parent incomes

Quantitative implication: Under the current income distribution, restoring mid-century levels of absolute mobility would require unrealistically high sustained real GDP per family growth rates above roughly 5% per year; alternatively, redistributing growth more broadly could largely restore mobility

Conclusion: Absolute income mobility in the United States has fallen sharply since 1940 and reviving high rates of absolute mobility requires economic growth that is shared more broadly across the income distribution rather than relying on higher aggregate growth alone
